text: Maybe that sounds more despair-inducing, but to me it reasserts our own agency in all of this. There is no "screwed" out there in the universe, like a meteor headed to earth. It's us, and we have the power to save ourselves from the very worst futures that are heading towards us
author: chrislhayes

text: Each additional fraction of a degree means more suffering and misery and disruption and we, as a human race, have to find some way to come together to avoid the most catastrophic outcomes, even though we're already going to get some truly awful ones.
author: chrislhayes

text: It is true that we *already* have a put a lot of warming into the system, with more to come. But there's an enormous difference between 2 degrees and 3 degrees, or 4 or even 8 (!)
author: chrislhayes

text: And what @dwallacewells does a really great job of showing is that "screwed" just doesn't capture the immense range of possibilities before us. And because it's not binary, it's not just "screwed" or "not scewed," we simply CANNOT shrug our shoulders.
author: chrislhayes

text: I think there's a very strong temptation to succumb to despair when you think seriously about the climate crisis. I feel that tug myself, and part of the way it manifests is the sentence "We're screwed!"

text:
I’m honored to host the Osborne Association’s annual fundraising breakfast and always come away inspired. They provide a range of services to and advocacy on behalf of the incarcerated and formerly incarcerated. Beautiful, life-affirming work.

author: chrislhayes

text:
The Solar Electric Light Fund brings sustainable, carbon-neutral electricity to energy-poor regions around the world. Arguably there is nothing more important for the future of the planet than bring zero-emission energy to the world’s poorest. 

http://www.self.org
author: chrislhayes

text:

text:

text: The decisions about prioritizarion are going to have massive consequences, and, to me, it’s one of the most central discussions within the Democratic Party over the next two years. It’s part of why the Green New Deal activism is so smart and politically important.
author: chrislhayes

text: Those two issues both didn’t get priority in Obama’s first two years, and the urgency has only grown. I think the stakes of climate are enormous and world-civilizational but the pressing, right-now, human stakes of immigration are too.

text: #Hottake 10: The Democratic party took big strides towards having a professional elected class that more closely looks like its voting coalition. The more of that the better both on the merits *and* the politics (See Lucy McBath).
author: chrislhayes

text: #Hottake 9: McCain's thumbs down, which killed ACA repeal, probably saved the GOP a bunch of house seats and some senate races. Much easier to walk away from the unpopularity of a bad vote than a bad law.
author: chrislhayes

text: #Hottake 8: The economy tends not to loom super large in midterms as a voting determinant but it does in presidentials and markets all sending signals (possibly erroneous) we are now in late cycle. Honestly, probably no single exogenous factor matters more than that.
author: chrislhayes

text: #Hottake 7: Sherrod Brown and Amy Klobuchar are underrated as 2020 D presidential contenders.
author: chrislhayes

text: #Hottake 6: Not a novel one, but still important: midwestern snap back in WI, MI, PA, OH is massively important for 2020. There will be lots of attention paid to the internals to figure out what happened and the answer matters *a lot.*
author: chrislhayes

text: #Hottake 5: The biggest problem for Dems to solve is how to reliably put together a high turnout, multi-racial multi-class coalition *while also eating into the margins among white non-college/rural voters*. That's a hard thing to do!
author: chrislhayes

text: #Hottake 4: There was no real, clear ideological through-line for Democrats last night: Joe Donnelly lost and so did Gillum. There was some real promise to the Beto, Abrams, Gillum theory of the case (be authentic, turn out your base, find new voters) but it was not quite enough
author: chrislhayes

text: #Hottake 3: The Trump coalition is running a fairly successful, and fairly unprecedented, experiment of governing the country from a bunker of 40 - 44% of the population. Constitutional structures help them massively in doing this, but it's a real problem for D's.
author: chrislhayes

text: #Hottake 2: The Democratic party's coalition is bigger than the GOP, BUT the GOP's hardcore, reliable voting base is bigger, and much more spread out across the country. Dems have to turnout lots of different kinds of voters, GOP doesn't really. Which leads to...
author: chrislhayes

text: #Hottake 1: D house performance in 2018 was comparable to GOP performance in 2010 for 2 reasons: overall pop vote margin was about the same and CRUCIALLY, D's had a much bigger majority in 2010 (257 seats!), so were overexposed. A GOP majority of 257 seats woulda lost 60 seats
author: chrislhayes

text: What employers want, and increasingly what they're getting, are no constraints on their own "speech" but total control over what their employees can and can't say. Nice deal if you can get it!
author: chrislhayes

text: At the same time, courts have expanded the free speech rights of corporations (read: employers). *And* used speech arguments to chip away at unions.
author: chrislhayes

text: This is viewpoint neutral, by the way. Your employer might fire you for a "F*ck Trump" sign or a "Deport All Immigrants!" sign. But either way, your expression isn't free, because in the back of your head you always know you can pay for it with your livelihood.
author: chrislhayes

text: But now we find ourselves with a situation in which the line between employee and citizen has been more or less annihilated by social media. You can clock out and go to a protest with a vulgar sign or post something on Facebook and end up fired.
author: chrislhayes

text: The vast majority of American workers are at-will employees who effectively have no free speech rights at work, a place where they spend half or more of their waking hours.
author: chrislhayes

text: It's notable to me that in all the discussion about free speech, and threats to it, that people don't talk more about employers.
author: chrislhayes
